concepts.name: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
concepts.description: A framework where multiple autonomous agents learn optimal policies through interaction with a shared environment, enabling decentralized decision-making. In this paper, it forms the core learning mechanism for coordinated AI agent behavior.

concepts.name: Secure Communication Protocols
concepts.description: Mechanisms that ensure confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity of data exchanged between agents. Integrated with MARL, they protect against eavesdropping, tampering, and spoofing in agent interactions.

concepts.name: End-to-End Encryption
concepts.description: A cryptographic method that encrypts data at the source and decrypts it only at the intended recipient, preventing unauthorized access during transmission. Used here to secure inter-agent communication in MARL systems.

concepts.name: Secure Key Exchange
concepts.description: A protocol enabling two parties to establish a shared secret key over an insecure channel. The paper employs Diffie-Hellman-based mechanisms to securely initialize encryption keys between agents.

concepts.name: Lightweight Identity Authentication
concepts.description: A minimal-overhead mechanism to verify the identity of agents before communication. Ensures only authorized agents participate in the MARL coordination process, reducing impersonation risks.

concepts.name: Adversarial Robustness
concepts.description: The ability of a system to maintain performance under malicious attacks such as message injection or policy manipulation. Evaluated in the paper through simulated attack scenarios.

concepts.name: Decentralized Training
concepts.description: A training paradigm where agents learn independently without a central controller, enhancing scalability and fault tolerance. Central to the proposed framework’s applicability in distributed systems.

concepts.name: Trustworthy AI
concepts.description: AI systems designed to be reliable, secure, and ethically aligned. The paper contributes to this domain by embedding security into the learning process, enabling safer multi-agent collaboration.

concepts.name: Cryptography Integration
concepts.description: The embedding of cryptographic primitives into machine learning workflows. Here, it enables secure exchange of policy updates and coordination signals in MARL.

concepts.name: Policy Coordination
concepts.description: The process by which agents align their behaviors to achieve collective goals. In this work, it is facilitated through encrypted, secure communication channels during MARL training.

concepts.name: Model Poisoning Defense
concepts.description: Protection against malicious manipulation of shared model parameters. The secure communication layer mitigates risks of adversarial policy updates in collaborative learning.

concepts.name: Zero-Knowledge Proofs
concepts.description: Cryptographic techniques allowing one party to prove knowledge of a value without revealing the value itself. Implied in identity authentication and secure coordination, though not explicitly detailed.

concepts.name: Distributed IoT Systems
concepts.description: Networks of interconnected devices operating in a decentralized manner. The framework is designed for scalability in such environments, particularly for autonomous agents in smart infrastructure.

concepts.name: Autonomous Robotics Coordination
concepts.description: The collaborative operation of multiple robots to achieve shared objectives. The paper’s framework supports secure, scalable coordination in robotic swarms.

concepts.name: Adversarial Testing
concepts.description: A method of evaluating system resilience by simulating attacks such as man-in-the-middle or message tampering. Used in the paper to benchmark security under realistic threat models.

concepts.name: Communication Overhead
concepts.description: The computational and bandwidth cost of transmitting encrypted data. A key concern in real-time systems, especially on resource-constrained devices.

concepts.name: Convergence Stability
concepts.description: The property of a learning algorithm to reach and maintain a stable solution over time. The paper notes a lack of long-term analysis on how security mechanisms affect MARL convergence.

concepts.name: Edge Computing Constraints
concepts.description: Resource limitations (e.g., memory, processing power) in edge devices. The paper acknowledges that encryption may impact real-time performance in such environments.

concepts.name: Sybil Attack Resistance
concepts.description: Defense against a single entity creating multiple fake identities to disrupt coordination. Implied in the identity authentication mechanism, though not explicitly tested.

concepts.name: Privacy-Preserving Learning
concepts.description: A paradigm where agents learn without exposing sensitive data. Achieved here through encrypted communication of policy updates and state information.

concepts.name: Attack Surface Reduction
concepts.description: Minimizing the number of potential entry points for adversaries. The integration of security into the MARL pipeline reduces the attack surface of agent interactions.

concepts.name: Dynamic Environment Adaptation
concepts.description: The ability of agents to adjust strategies in response to changing conditions. The framework supports this through continuous, secure policy updates.

concepts.name: Cryptographic Non-Repudiation
concepts.description: Ensuring that an agent cannot deny having sent a message. Supported by authentication and encryption mechanisms, enhancing accountability in agent interactions.

concepts.name: Secure Policy Sharing
concepts.description: The process of exchanging learned policies between agents in a way that prevents interception or modification. Enabled via encrypted channels in the proposed framework.

concepts.name: Simulation-Based Evaluation
concepts.description: Assessment of system performance in virtual environments before real-world deployment. Used extensively in the paper to test security and task performance.

concepts.name: Task Performance Parity
concepts.description: The condition where a secure system achieves performance comparable to an insecure baseline. Demonstrated in the paper as a key success metric.

concepts.name: Inter-Agent Trust
concepts.description: The confidence agents have in each other’s reliability and honesty. The framework assumes trustworthiness, limiting defense against internal malicious agents.

concepts.name: Model Inversion Attack
concepts.description: An attack where an adversary infers sensitive training data from model outputs. The paper notes this threat is not fully evaluated in the current work.

concepts.name: Strategy Manipulation
concepts.description: An adversarial technique where an agent alters its policy to mislead others. The framework is tested against such attacks to validate robustness.

concepts.name: Scalable Multi-Agent Systems
concepts.description: Systems capable of supporting large numbers of agents without performance degradation. The proposed framework supports this through decentralized training and secure coordination.

concepts.name: Real-Time System Constraints
concepts.description: Performance requirements for systems that must respond within strict time limits. The paper identifies encryption overhead as a potential bottleneck in such systems.

concepts.name: Security-Efficiency Trade-off
concepts.description: The balance between implementing strong security measures and maintaining system performance. The paper emphasizes achieving this balance through integrated design.

concepts.name: Collaborative Learning Security
concepts.description: The protection of shared learning processes from malicious interference. A central theme of the paper, addressed via secure communication and authentication.

concepts.name: Adaptive Security Framework
concepts.description: A security system that evolves with changing threats and environments. The proposed framework is designed to be self-adaptive through integrated learning and security mechanisms.

concepts.name: Trust Model Assumptions
concepts.description: The foundational belief that agents follow protocols and are not malicious. The paper acknowledges this as a limitation, as internal threats are not modeled.

concepts.name: End-to-End Secure Coordination
concepts.description: A holistic approach where all communication and coordination steps are secured from origin to destination. Core to the paper’s contribution in enabling secure MARL.

concepts.name: Cryptographic Policy Integrity
concepts.description: Ensuring that shared policies are not altered during transmission. Achieved via encryption and authentication, critical for maintaining learning consistency.

concepts.name: Distributed Consensus Security
concepts.description: The secure agreement among agents on shared states or actions. Supported by authenticated, encrypted communication in the framework.

concepts.name: Attack Resilience Metrics
concepts.description: Quantitative measures of system performance under adversarial conditions. Used in the paper to compare secure vs. non-secure MARL systems.

methods.name: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
methods.description: A decentralized learning framework where multiple agents learn optimal policies through interaction with a shared environment. In this study, it is used to train agents to coordinate tasks while sharing encrypted policy updates.

methods.name: End-to-End Encryption
methods.description: Data is encrypted at the sender’s end and decrypted only at the receiver’s end, ensuring confidentiality. Applied to all inter-agent communication during MARL training and policy updates.

methods.name: Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange
methods.description: A cryptographic protocol enabling two agents to securely establish a shared secret key over an insecure channel. Used in the paper to initialize secure communication sessions between agents.

methods.name: Lightweight Identity Authentication
methods.description: A minimal-cost method to verify agent identities using digital signatures or tokens. Implemented to prevent unauthorized agents from joining the coordination process.

methods.name: Adversarial Simulation
methods.description: A method of testing system robustness by simulating attacks such as man-in-the-middle, message injection, and policy spoofing. Used to evaluate the framework’s resilience under active threats.

methods.name: Simulation Platform Evaluation
methods.description: Performance assessment using established MARL simulation environments like MADRL and PyMARL. Used to compare secure and non-secure MARL systems across multiple metrics.

methods.name: Task Success Rate Measurement
methods.description: A metric quantifying the percentage of episodes in which agents successfully complete a given task. Used to evaluate whether security mechanisms affect performance.

methods.name: Security Metric Benchmarking
methods.description: Quantitative evaluation of communication security using metrics such as message integrity failure rate and encryption overhead. Used to compare secure vs. baseline systems.

methods.name: Decentralized Training
methods.description: A training approach where each agent learns independently using local observations and shared policy updates. Enables scalability and fault tolerance in large agent networks.

methods.name: Policy Update Encryption
methods.description: The process of encrypting learned policy parameters before transmission between agents. Ensures that policy sharing remains secure and tamper-proof.

methods.name: Secure Communication Channel Setup
methods.description: A procedure involving key exchange, authentication, and encryption initialization to establish a trusted link between agents. Implemented prior to any policy coordination.

methods.name: Robustness Testing
methods.description: An experimental method to assess system behavior under adversarial conditions. In this paper, it involves injecting malicious messages and observing system response.

methods.name: Comparative Analysis
methods.description: A method of evaluating performance by comparing two or more systems (e.g., secure vs. non-secure MARL). Used to demonstrate the trade-off between security and efficiency.

methods.name: Cryptographic Protocol Integration
methods.description: The embedding of cryptographic protocols (e.g., encryption, key exchange) directly into the MARL training loop. Enables real-time secure coordination during learning.

methods.name: End-to-End Secure Coordination
methods.description: A method where all coordination steps—from policy sharing to action execution—are secured using encryption and authentication. Central to the framework’s design.

methods.name: Attack Vector Simulation
methods.description: A simulation-based method to model specific attack types (e.g., message tampering, strategy deception) and measure their impact on system performance.

methods.name: Convergence Monitoring
methods.description: A technique to track the learning progress of agents over time, assessing whether security mechanisms affect the stability or speed of convergence.

methods.name: Overhead Measurement
methods.description: A method to quantify computational and communication costs introduced by security mechanisms, particularly relevant for edge deployment.

methods.name: Trust Assumption Analysis
methods.description: A method to evaluate the impact of assuming agent trustworthiness on system security, used to identify limitations in the current framework.

methods.name: Security-Performance Trade-off Analysis
methods.description: A method to balance security enhancements with system efficiency, using metrics like task success rate and encryption latency to guide design decisions.
